summary_reasoning: The report contains several company-specific details but offers limited original insight. Most analytical statements are restatements of public narratives (moat from S&P 500 and ratings duopoly, synergies from IHS Markit, macro sensitivity of Ratings). The valuation section provides a DCF with standard assumptions (7–9% revenue CAGR, 100–200 bps margin expansion, ~8.5% WACC) and a fair value of $585, but it lacks novel drivers or mechanisms beyond widely discussed tailwinds (ESG, index-linked AUM, spinoff execution). There is at most one weak synthesis linking assumptions to fair value; no unique thesis with catalysts or quantification tied to decision-relevant, company-distinct angles (e.g., segment-specific levers, issuance cycles, index fee beta to market levels). The report presents minimal peer contrast and does not introduce monitoring signals or timelines. Decision relevance is modest: the fair value and EPS bridge are actionable but rely on generic inputs. With ≥3 insights restated/generic and no clear original thesis, originality is capped at Fair.

insights_classified.text: Spinning off Mobility will allow focus on four core businesses and drive enhanced operational efficiency and clearer investment positioning.
IHS Markit integration continues to generate meaningful synergies, enhancing data capabilities and cross-selling opportunities.
S&P Global’s wide moat stems from the S&P 500 benchmark, switching costs, and a regulatory-protected ratings duopoly.
Fair value of $585 based on 7–9% revenue CAGR, 100–200 bps margin expansion, and ~8.5% WACC.
EPS projected to reach $18–20 by 2029; at 29–31x forward earnings this supports the $585 fair value.
Operating leverage from fixed-cost infrastructure provides sensitivity to revenue upside above base case.

red_flags: Generic DCF with no novel drivers
Standard risk list without company-specific angle
